image.altText: A man wearing a tie stands indoors, looking ahead. A neutral expression on his face.

props.synopsis: Australia's airline graveyard is littered with failed carriers â€“ with two more joining the ranks of the fallen this year. Bill Astling believes he has what it takes to break into the market.

title.children: 'You have to be insane': This man says he's starting Australia's next airline

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a shady tree

props.synopsis: A consumer group has advised Australians to "shop around" for cheaper groceries, but for people in regional areas, choice is a luxury they don't have.

title.children: 'We don't have a choice': Regional Australians paying the price of supermarket duopoly

image.altText: Police recruits marching

props.synopsis: Thousands of vacancies for police officers across Australia are making it harder for forces to protect the public, unions say.

title.children: Police are leaving the force 'in droves' with thousands of unfilled positions intensifying workloads

image.altText: A sign that says protect water

props.synopsis: An environment group has launched another legal attack on plans to frack the Beetaloo Basin in an "unprecedented" legal setting arguing the US gas company's project poses unacceptable risks to water.

title.children: NT government, gas firm face another Beetaloo Basin fracking challenge under novel 'third party' laws

image.altText: Shadeene Evans wears a light blue soccer shirt with the number 17 on it, and looks into the camera while standing on a field.

props.synopsis: Indigenous Football Week, supported by A-League player Shadeene Evans, is highlighting a program creating change in remote communities.

title.children: Here's why Indigenous Football Week means so much to the A-League's Shadeene Evans

image.altText: A split image showing a police vehicle parked next to a marquee on an outback road and a man with dark hair and a moustache.

props.synopsis: Gary John Schmidt's remains were discovered on the outskirts of Kununurra in 2015. Genetic genealogy technology has finally allowed authorities to identify him, but the circumstances surrounding his death remain mysterious.

title.children: Identity of man whose body was found on outback highway confirmed after almost 10 years

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous woman sits beside the red road with a rake and bucket.

props.synopsis:
Food insecurity leads to disastrous health outcomes for the most the isolated. Some believe a focus on native ingredients could help turn things around.Â 

Â

title.children: Many Australians struggle with chronic diseases. Daisy believes native 'superfood' could improve their health

image.altText: Singer Slim Dusty leans on a car near Uluru

props.synopsis: Australia's "King of Country Music" performed for a number of remote Queensland towns over his 60-year career, and the communities have never forgotten it.

title.children: Why Slim Dusty's friendship with Indigenous Australia is worth singing about

image.altText: A large amount of rubble, with smoke also visible rising from it

props.synopsis: Israel's attacks in Lebanon will continue for the foreseeable future, a military spokesperson and the country's PM say, despite confirmation Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the country's main adversary there, had been "eliminated".

title.children: Israel 'determined to keep fighting' in Lebanon despite assassinating Hezbollah chief

image.altText: A man speaks into a microphone with his hand in the air

props.synopsis: The leader of the region's most powerful militia and Iran's strongest ally is gone, and Hezbollah, the group he headed, has been decimated by intense Israel attacks. But that doesn't mean it will die with him.

title.children: Nasrallah turned an Islamist militia into a political force that will outlive him

image.altText: albanese walks down a corridor holding papers, a grimace on his face

props.synopsis: With less than a year until the next election, the words of party elder Gough Whitlam could be ringing in Anthony Albanese's ears.Â

title.children: 'Frightened to put a foot wrong': The 40-year-old quote that rings true for Albanese today

image.altText: A white man with facial difference standing outside and leaning on a brick wall

props.synopsis: A year on from the disability royal commission's final report, ABC NEWS takes a closer look at one of the biggest and most contentious proposals for change â€” phasing out segregated employment.

title.children: 'An affront to dignity': The system allowing people with disability to be paid $6 an hour

image.altText: Sugra Barkati walks with supporters while being escorted by armed soldiers.

props.synopsis: The 17-year-old and her brother, 11, emerge as unexpected symbols of resilience as they draw crowds to rallies across Kashmir and campaign for their father â€” a jailed separatist.Â

title.children: How a teen girl became a symbol of resistance amid tense elections in Indian-controlled Kashmir

image.altText: A group of Sydney Swans AFL players sit and stand on the MCG after a losing grand final, looking dejected.

props.synopsis: The Swans hoped the thrashing by Geelong in the 2022 grand final was a one-off, but their latest thumping by Brisbane reveals a worrying pattern that will no doubt add to the soul-searching at Sydney.

title.children: Deja vu in the worst way as Swans suffer another grand final disaster

image.altText: Kristen and Warren look down at their son Patrick, both smiling, as he pats a cat on the head.

props.synopsis: When Andrew Leech trained as a GP 11 years ago, he thought the main issues he'd be seeing in children would be coughs and colds. He wasn't anticipating the wave of children and teens battling mental health problems.Â

title.children: 'It's cruel' and 'He'll grow out of it': Parents' decision to medicate their children is met with judgement

image.altText: A man in a suit sitting and speaking, with his arms raised, gesturing

props.synopsis: Trump is hoping to win a second term as US president in November. Here's what that would mean for the criminal cases against him.Â

title.children: What happens with Trump's criminal cases if he wins the election?

image.altText: Photo: Matt Davis

props.synopsis: Exposure to violence defined Darryl's early life, before he turned to violence himself. Today, Darryl teaches positive masculinity and uses boxing to empower communities and help break the cycle.

title.children: 'People say I'm very peaceful. They don't know how much violence it took to be this gentle'

image.altText: An orange flash had been enveloped by the great uprush of water. Immense clouds of smoke, steam and spray burst into the air.

props.synopsis: Indonesia and Solomon Islands have signed up to ban the bomb. Experts say Australia's reluctance to do so could spur tension with its neighbours.

title.children: Why some argue Australia wants 'to have cake and eat it too' on nuclear weapons

image.altText: Two men face off during a rugby league match

props.synopsis: Four years after they first met in a grand final, Penrith's clash with Melbourne is the moment the club's record-breaking dynasty comes full circle.

title.children: Penrith's grand final clash with Melbourne is a return to the beginning of their dynasty

image.altText: A tin shed partially submerged in floodwaters

props.synopsis: The Nepalese government says all divisions of security forces in the country, including the army, have been ordered to help in the rescue efforts.

title.children: More than 60 killed, dozens injured and stranded amid flooding and landslides in Nepal

image.altText: Jannik Sinner holds the Australian Open trophy after winning the 2024 men's final.

props.synopsis: The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) has appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport against an independent tribunal's decision in August to clear tennis world number one Jannik Sinner of wrongdoing after he failed drug tests.

title.children: WADA appeals decision to clear Jannik Sinner of wrongdoing after failed drug tests

image.altText: Three young people sit on the floor of an office, leaning against a wall, smiling.

props.synopsis: Many Australians are neurodivergent, yet some don't disclose this to employers for fear of discrimination. So how practical is it to create a neurodivergent-friendly workplace?Â

title.children: Nearly half of the staff at this agency are neurodivergent. The CEO says there are real benefits for her bottom line

image.altText: Two fisheries patrol boats on the water

props.synopsis: Fisheries officers in NSW say they are facing increasingly dangerous situations when dealing with poachers and organised crime gangs and are calling for better workplace protections.

title.children: Fisheries officers demand stab-proof vests and capsicum spray saying poachers and criminal gangs make their jobs too dangerous

image.altText: Small white dog with cocked head

props.synopsis: A group of Sydney veterinarian clinics say there are daily reports of pets in a critical condition during tick season, some with potentially fatal paralysis tick bites.

title.children: Vets warn Sydney pet owners that tick season could be one of the 'worst' yet with unpredictable weather

image.altText: A composite image of flour made from lupin and lupin beans still on the plant.

props.synopsis: Lupin is traditionally used to feed cattle in Australia but aged care facilities are now adding it to their residents' food. The nutrition results experienced in the program are being labelled as "remarkable".

title.children: Turning cattle feed into nutritional flour for aged care residents

image.altText: Overhead shot of stilt houses surrounded by damaged parts from buildings floating around in a waterway

props.synopsis: Hurricane Helene caused dozens of deaths and billions of dollars' worth of destruction across several states in the south-eastern United States.

title.children: Dozens dead and millions still without power after Helene's deadly march across south-eastern US

image.altText: Treasure Boxes volunteers  2024-06-25 09:06:00

props.synopsis: Thousands of pregnant women in Australia are going hungry with half of those too scared to ask for help, according to new research.

title.children: One in 10 expecting mothers are going hungry, survey finds

image.altText: three pages of legislation

props.synopsis: Current abortion legislation has been in effect for little more than two years, but a conservative MP argues it's time for more changes. And it comes despite concerns within his own party about his plan, Rory McClaren writes.

title.children: Abortion laws are once again being debated in SA, but some are wondering why

image.altText: Isaah Yeo of the Panthers is tackled by the Storm defence

props.synopsis: We're now a week away from the climax of the 2024 season, but while we know the men's teams, we won't find out who's made it to the women's finals until later this evening.Â

title.children: What you need to know ahead of rugby league's grand final day

image.altText: Chris Fagan and the Brisbane Lions with the AFL premiership cup.

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lions coach Chris Fagan admits his side "were looking down the barrel" at the halfway mark of the season, before recovering to reach the finals and claim the club's first AFL premiership since 2003.

title.children: Resilience, hard work and Ted Lasso: How Fagan and the Lions fought back to achieve premiership glory

image.altText: A composite image of Jim Chalmers and Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: Labor's inability to come clean about who ordered the Treasury to work on negative gearing left the government and prime minister Anthony Albanese smeared as tricky, dissembling and guilty of treating voters with contempt.

title.children: 48 hours of confusion has backfired on Labor, when they could have just come clean

image.altText: A picture of cyclist Muriel Furrer on a screen

props.synopsis: Cycling has lost another rider due to a downhill crash, with teenager Muriel Furrer killed on a descent at the World Championships in Zurich. So where does the responsibility lie?

title.children: 'We are nothing on Earth and even less on a bike': The intrinsic failings and risks of cycling laid bare with another premature death
